description: From Middle English opposen, from Old French opposer, from Latin ob (“before, against”) + Medieval Latin pono (“to put”), taking the place of Latin opponere (“to oppose”).

verbs.description: oppose (third-person singular simple present opposes, present participle opposing, simple past and past participle opposed)

entries.meaning: To attempt to stop the progression of; to resist or antagonize by physical means, or by arguments, etc.; to contend against.
examples: Synonyms: confront, withstand, resist, hinder, obstruct, buck
to oppose the king in battle
to oppose a bill in Congress
There is still time to oppose this plan.
Synonyms: take issue with, speak out, contest, repugn, argue
Many religious leaders oppose cloning humans.

entries.meaning: To present or set up in opposition; to pose.
examples: They are opposed to any form of hierarchy.

entries.meaning: To place in front of, or over against; to set opposite; to exhibit.
